Commercial Carpet Consultants Inc. pleaded guilty to a violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act by participating in a conspiracy to fix the prices of commercial flooring and services. It agreed to pay a $1.2 million criminal fine.

Cargill, Sanderson Farms and Wayne Farms agreed to pay a total of more than $84 million to settle allegations that they violated antitrust laws by sharing poultry workers wage and benefit information.

Cargill, Sanderson Farms and Wayne Farms agreed to pay a total of more than $84 million to settle allegations that they violated antitrust laws by sharing poultry workers wage and benefit information.
Current Parent Ownership Structure: joint venture (owned by Cargill and Continental Grain)

Description: Cargill, Sanderson Farms and Wayne Farms agreed to pay a total of more than $84 million to settle allegations that they violated antitrust laws by sharing poultry workers wage and benefit information.
Current Parent Ownership Structure: joint venture (owned by Cargill and Continental Grain)

Description: Axion Specialty Contracting LLC was sentenced to pay a $1,001,989 criminal fine and $313,121 in restitution for its participation in a bid-rigging scheme targeting public and private entities in Connecticut.

VDA OC LLC (VDA), a health care staffing company, pleaded guilty and was sentenced for entering into and engaging in a conspiracy with a competitor to allocate employee nurses and to fix the wages of those nurses.
participation in bid-rigging and fraud schemes targeting public and private entities in Connecticut

The Department of Justice filed a proposed amended complaint and consent decreein the District of Maryland with George's Inc. and George's Foods LLC that would resolve claims that George's conspired with other poultry processors for years to suppress workers' wages by exchanging compensation information (wage-fixing). George's agreed to pay $5.8 million in restitution for poultry processing plant workers who were harmed by the conspiracy.

The Justice Department announced deferred prosecution agreements resolving criminal antitrust charges against Teva Pharmaceuticals USA, Inc. and Glenmark Pharmaceuticals Inc., USA  focusing on price-fixing of the cholesterol drug pravastatin. As part of those agreements, both companies will divest a key business line involved in the misconduct, and as an additional remedial measure, Teva will make a $50 million drug donation to humanitarian organizations. Teva will pay a $225 million criminal penalty and Glenmark will pay a $30 million criminal penalty.

The Justice Department announced deferred prosecution agreements resolving criminal antitrust charges against Teva Pharmaceuticals USA, Inc. and Glenmark Pharmaceuticals Inc., USA  focusing on price-fixing of the cholesterol drug pravastatin. As part of those agreements, both companies will divest a key business line involved in the misconduct, and as an additional remedial measure, Teva will make a $50 million drug donation to humanitarian organizations. Teva will pay a $225 million criminal penalty and Glenmark will pay a $30 million criminal penalty.

J&J Korea Inc., a company based in South Korea, was sentenced by a federal judge in Texas to pay nearly $9 million dollars in a criminal fine and restitution for rigging bids and committing fraud in connection with subcontract work at U.S. military installations in South Korea.
participating in a conspiracy to fix the prices of DVDs and Blu-Ray Discs sold on the Amazon marketplace

On October 30, 2023, the Department of Justice, Antitrust Division, and the United States Attorney's Office for the District of North Dakota entered into a non-prosecution agreement with Pro-Mark Services, Inc. Between 2008 and 2020, Pro-Mark's former owners were said to have executed a scheme to obtain government set-aside construction contracts for the company, amounting to approximately $70 million in federal contracts being awarded, despite Pro-Mark not being eligible to compete for these contracts. The former owners then cashed out of company, selling it to Pro-Mark's employees via an employee stock ownership plan (ESOP) transaction. The NPA required the company to pay a penalty of $949,000 and to continue implementing a compliance and ethics program.
